Muller Announces
Increase in Tuition
by Bill Riesen
University President Steven
Muller formally announced a
9.3 percent tuition increase at a
special meeting with the Student Council Wednesday.
Muller discussed reasons for the
increase and what tuition
dollars will be spent for. He
also answered questions from
the council about the effects of
cuts in federal student aid, and
about student participation in
university development plans.
The increase would send tuition from $8600 this year to
$9400 for the 1985-86 academic
year.
The university budget committee unanimously approved
the $800 hike last week, Muller
said, and the Board of Trustees
will hear the proposal Friday.
It is extremely unlikely the

Trustees will reject Muller's
recommendation.
He stressed that, "Johns
Hopkins' tuition today and
next year and into the indefinite
future will remain significantly
below that of other institutions." He distibuted a list to
the council members and halfdozen other students present of
93 prominent American colleges and universities ranked by
1984-1985 tuition rates. Johns
Hopkins is 48th on the list. If
Hopkins moves up on the list
because of the increase, Muller
said, he expects it will be by only a few places. "We really
don't want to raise tuition any
more than we have to," he said.
Muller maintained, however,
that some increase is needed to
update the Homewood departContinued on Page 3

As in the past two years, beer
sales at this year's Spring Fair
will be limited to a "Beer
Garden," according to Fair CoChairmen Mike Vogelbaum
and Bryce Quayle.
Vogelbaum and Quayle announced the alcohol policy at
Wednesday night's Student
Council meeting.
"Basically, it (the beer
policy) is going to be the same
as last year," Vogelbaum said.
As in past years, the "Beer
Garden" will be fenced off,
and only those of legal drinking age will be allowed inside,
Vogelbaum said. He also said
that there will probably be
seven student groups selling
beer, which is the same number
as last year.
"It's (selling beer)important
both to the Fair and student
groups financially," Vogelbaum said. "It brings in a lot
of money." Vogelbaum added
that this was true for the student groups only if they didn't
"drink away their profits,"
which the Fair discourages
them from doing, he said.
Prior to two years ago, when
the legal drinking age in
Maryland was 18 for beer and
wine, beer was sold throughout
the Fair.
Student Council President
Jon Lana asked Vogelbaum
and Quayle to explain the
financial benefits of selling
beer, which he said are in addition to the "carnal pleasures"
of the beverage. Lana offered
no explanation for the peculiar
wording.

Engineering to Hold
Onen House Saturday
The G.W.C. Whiting School
of Engineering will hold its annual Open House for high
school students, their parents,
and guidance counselors
tomorrow, the final day of National Engineers Week.
The event is designed to help
students decide if they want to
become engineers, and to tell
them about the educational opportunities in the Whiting

School.
Open to the public without
charge, the school's 12th Open
House will feature faculty
presentations, demonstrations,
and tours of the Homewood
campus facilities. This year's
activities will include the highly
entertaining "Fun With
Materials" lecture by Hopkins
professors Robert Green and
Robert Pond.

see," but emphasized that
amenities will be secondary to
academic improvements.
"We are considering the need
to add to the athletic facilities,
but it would be a lie to say that
this tuition increase is aimed to
support that," he said. "At this
point, our primary responsibility is the equality and integrity
of our academic program, and
additional income will be
directed primarily for that
purpose."
When asked whether proposed limitations in federal aid to
students were considered in the
decision to raise tuition, Muller
said, "No, they weren't taken
into account. There is no way
to take them into account"
because the federal proposals
will probably not take their
final form and be enacted until
early fall, which is too late for
the university to accommodate
the cuts in its own budget.
"I think it would be a
mistake to assume that there
will not be some new restrictions on federal aid to
students," he said. "But it
would be an equal mistake to
assume that Congress will pass
the cuts as proposed.. .If the
administration's proposal—as
so obnoxiously defended by
Secretary of Education William
Bennett—were passed, we
would not reconsider the tuition
increase, but would have to
make a drastic reassessment of
our financial aid program."
The extent of consideration
given to undergraduate student
interests in making high-level
decisions about the development of the university was
another topic the Council
discussed with Muller. "We're
concerned about the priorities
that decide how our tuition
money is used," said Council
President Jon Lana.
Kathie Eubanks, Council
Vice-President, remarked that
it is difficult for students to
bring about significant changes.
She cited a student-led project
to revise the Hopkins January
intersession program which has
been sent from one group to a
other within the university
academic structure for the past
several months.
"There's a feeling of frustration," she said.."When you try
to do something as simple as get
changes made in the intersession program and nothing happens, you wonder whether
students can really do anything
to have an effect on the
university."
Muller replied that "The biggest difficulty is the inevitable
short range perspective of
students and the inevitable long
range perspective of the administration." Several projects
to improve student life are
underway, he said, including
redecorating and refurnishing
Levering Hall, constructing
new recreational space for the
dorms, and renovating the
snack bar. "From the student's
perspective," he admitted, "all
of these things are less interesting if they occur after the
student has graduated."

problems," Drell said, "which
one simply cannot escape."
Chief among these is the
reliability of the system. "An
effective defense system must
have a very much higher standard of reliability than any
other military defense in
history," said Drell. "The issue
of reliability is further confounded by the fact that most
of such a system would be based on scientific developments
that have yet to be achieved.
The system, which must "work
reliably in a hostile environment," must also "work essentially perfectly the first time you

turn it on."
Reagan's call for a national
effort to pursue such developments seemed dangerous to
Drell for several reasons, the
greatest of which was its probable infractions against the
SALT I Treaty, which is of
unlimited duration. Although
he "would be delighted to pay
one trillion dollars for an effective defense system," he stated
that "We do not know how to
build a comprehensive national
defense system, as a technical
judgement, I do not think it
exists."
Drell then outlined the course
which he feels science should
take in the coming years. He

stated his support not for a
crash program but for "a
measured research program
such as we now have that is intended as a hedge against
technology."
Such a program would stay
within the ABM treaty and
would not further upset the
stability which is the only real
product of MAD. He also called for scientific advice at the
operational level, stating that
"the present program is a vision
without scientific input."

Drell's major points, Strobe

A Century of Change
Today is Commemoration Day,
celebrating the 109th year of existence of the
Johns Hopkins University. As part of the
festivities, President Muller and faculty
members will don their academic garb and
honor an institution which has exemplified
higher education in America for the last century. They will likewise acclaim the progressive changes accompanying such
maturity.
We at the News-Letter were curious as to
whether major student concerns have
similarly developed over our many years.
After hours of rummaging through old
News-Letter editorials, we came up with the
following interesting excerpts.
LI

Complaints concerning fraternity parties
and general behavior have been coming to
the Dean's office all year. Discounting the
usual and expected complaints of cranks, the

Insensitivity
To the Editor:
Valentine's Day is certainly
not a major holiday. Yet it does
provide the opportunity for expressing one's love for another
person. It was within this con-

text that the cartoon Hopper
appeared in the February 15
edition of the News-Letter. The
message of the strip seemed
clear: Hopper apparently hates
Valentine's Day because he
never received valentines from
the "cool people" in elementary school, but he did receive
valentines from the "faggots"
in high school. Let me suggest
what is wrong with this.
First, the cartoon almsot explicitly connects unpopularity,
or "uncoolness" with homosexuality. Indeed, the adjustments to and expression of
one's homosexuality are not
always easy, but the fact of being a homosexual is hardly
related to one's ability to
achieve success or respect. Unfortunately, the cartoon conveys the more implicit and insidious suggestion that love between or expressed by homosexuals is unacceptable or unnatural. All the more distressing
is the apparent widespread acceptance of this attitude among
the Hopkins community. Such
insensitivity is the very essence
of bigotry. To be sure, the use
of the word "faggot" in a
newspaper which allegedly
represents Hopkins is shocking.
All the academic pestige and
clout of Hopkins does not
justify the use of the word
"faggot" in any context. I can
only imagine what effect this
cartoon had on those who are
struggling with their own sexual
identity, who are frustrated,
confused, or alienated. That
these people on the very
threshold of sexual ambiguity
should be subjected to such
cruelty is reprehensible and unforgivable. I cannot understand
why love—an emotion so
necessary for everyone and
something which bears all
things, believes all things, hopes
all things, endures all things—
why this should be legitimate
for some but not others.
Irrespective of whatever
humorous effect the strip's
message was intended to produce (which I failed to
discover), such a pejorative cartoon should never have been
published. There are universities and communities in the

tbe

United States which would have
not only voiced significant
outrage, but would have
mobilized demonstrations
within hours of the cartoon's
appearance. I have written this
letter to voice my personal
outrage, but whether it will provoke even the slightest reaction
is problematic. It is an attempt,
however small, to break the
tyranny of silence which exists
concerning the problems faced
by homosexuals, both male and
female, in the Hopkins community. It is my hope that those
who feel frustrated, hurt, or
angered, will see that there are
people who care and understand very much, and that they
are not alone.
Scott Henderson
Graduate Student, Department
of History

Letters continued
Continued from Page 6
ter to a friend, and sends it
through the U.S. Mail. The letter contains comments critical
of the local postmaster. It turns
out that the letter cannot be
delivered or returned, so it is
sent to the Dead Letter Office.
The letter is opened and the
contents are passed on to the
postmaster, who then sends a
note to Mr. Carpenter commenting on his letter and
threatening to cut off his mail
delivery.
This is precisely what happened with my electronic letter.
Reading the first few lines(with
the "From:" and "To:"
headings) may have been
necessary to deliver or return it.
However, by concerning
himself with the contents of
private correspondence, David
Binko did commit an invasion
of privacy. His threat of taking
"steps to limit [my] communications to the outside
world to 'AT & Tnet' "—

because of the contents of my
letter—was an attempt to infringe freedom of speech as well.
I commend the editors of
theNews-Letter for their wellwritten editorial that went
directly to the real issue. They,
as well as the Student Council,
recognized that no matter how
legitimately Homewood Computing Facilities personnel obtained access to the letter, it
could not justify Mr. Binko's
subsequent actions.
Johns Hopkins joined the
Bitnet computer network in
order to better serve all
members of the University
community. This includes using
the network for electronic mail
as well as more obviously
"educational" purposes such as
dissertations and up-to-theminute research results. It costs
the University exactly as much
to have the Bitnet connection
used heavily by students, faculty, and staff as it would to have
it sit idly.

Nobody I know has ever continued playing games in
Maryland 109 when someone
needed a terminal for real
work. On the contrary, my
knowlegeable "cronies" and I
have given thousands of hours
of assistance over the last four
years to many people desperately trying to complete computer
projects. I wonder if Mr.
Carpenter has talked to any of
these people. Any of us will
gladly help him take advantage
of the powerful resources of the,
computer networks available to
everyone at this University.
I regret that a faculty
member received negative
publicity through no fault of his
own, but rather because private
correspondence did not stay
private. The entire incident
never should have happened.
Sincerely,
Adlai Waksman, '85

animals. After each extinction,
the very few surviving species
would repopulate the areas
previously inhabited by others.
It was found that the one or
two surviving species after each
extinction were suited to dwell
in colder waters. This suggests
that each extinction coincided
with a drop in sea temperature.
In the last part of the
Mesozoic era, 100 million years
ago, known as the Cretaceous
Period, another remarkable
mass extinction occurred. During the Cretaceous crisis, many
groups of algae were wiped out.
Some of these were the type
that had created large deposits
of chalk on the sea floor, as
seen in the white cliffs of
Dover. During this time reefbuilding rudists, similar to corals, many species of snails, and
all species of ammonoids
(swimming mollusks with spiral
shells), became extinct. This extinction was again characterized by a tropical bias. That is,
species living in warmer
climates were more affected
than others. Other evidence for
cooling includes analyses of
fossil leaves from the period
which indicates a five to twelve
degree (Celcius) drop in
temperature.
The end of the Mesozoic age
was also the end of the age of
dinosaurs. A recent hypothesis
suggests that the extinction of

the great reptiles was caused by
the impact of an asteroid on the
earth. Supposedly, after the impact, large amounts of dust
were raised, obscuring the sun.
The evidence for this is a thin
geologic layer around the world
that contains a higher than
average concentration of
iridium, which is scarce on the
earth's surface while abundant
on asteroids.
This hypothesis, however,
necessarily implies that the extinctions at the end of the
Cretaceous Period would have
been quite sudden. This is not
supported by other evidence.
While some species do indeed
demonstrate a sudden disappearance, many others show a
natural decline in the same
period. Different groups of
organisms declined at different
times during this period over a
duration of two million years.
The mass extinctions Stanley
spoke of were quite extensive.
Some extinctions may have
eliminated up to 90 percent of
marine life and up to half of the
families of organisms. Stanley
did not speculate to a great extent as to what caused the
catastrophic coolings. Possibilities include changing properties of the sun, fluctuations in
the earth's orbit, or volcanic activity causing prolonged
obscuring of the sun.

effects.

coworker, Narcotics Detective

Sommer), is involved as well
(the latter realization being the
direct result of a gunshot
wound in the stomach).
Book rushes Rachel and
Samuel back to Lancaster
County, where he collapses
from blood loss. The Amish
doctor admits that Book's
wound is out of his league, but
Rachel insists that Book be
treated within the community.
This is not out of gratitude
towards the man who kept her
in Philadelphia longer than she
cared to stay; it is out of fear
for her son's life. Rachel knows
that if Book is put into a
hospital, the police will easily
track him down and use Book
as a stepping stone to get to the
one and only witness.
Needless to say, the traditional remedies equalled or exceeded hospital care. Book is
on his feet in no time, and is
forced to start pulling his
weight. The film is once again
seen through the eyes of the
newcomer, but that newcomer
is now Harrison Ford. Whether
or not he accepts them, Ford
gradually learns the Amish
ways and assimilates as best he

can.
The movie succeeds so spectacularly because director Weir,
along with first-time scripters
Earl W. Wallace and William
Kelley, never shows either side
winning in the clash of
cultures. Perhaps Book learns
a little about simple values,
such as the pleasures of an
honest day's work, or how to
satiate a thirst by savoring
lemonade one sip at a time. But
Rachel, too, learns pleasures
she did not know before: the
most simple of songs from
Book's car stereo brings an entirely new enjoyment to her until Grandpa Lapp takes Rachel
to task offscreen, presumably
about the evils of music, dance,
and radio.
In one of the movie's most
memorable scenes, Book puts
his carpentry skills to use as one
of a team that erects an entire
barn in a matter of hours. The
scene demonstrates not only
amazing teamwork, but gives
us further insight into Amish
male/female relations: the men
raise the barn, the women make
the lunch, and everyone involved knows their place.
Eventually, John and Rachel
become attracted to one
another, but both realize that
more than a simple one night
stand is at stake. The battle of
the cultures comes into play
once again, as they realize any

Sports
by Howard Bregman

The Mid-Atlantic Conference swimming season ends
this weekend as the Johns
Hopkins men's and women's
teams host the 38th annual conference championships at the
Homewood pool. The Jays will
host 13 varsity squads, all seeking team and individual
achievement at the climax of
their dual meet schedules.
,Hopkins Coach Tim Welsh is
looking forward to a competitive meet in both the men's
and women's ranks, as many
swimmers will attempt to
qualify for the Division III National Championships with
their performance at MAC's.
The national meet will be held
in Atlanta late next month.
"MAC's are important to us
in one respect because it is the
only meet to which the whole
team can go," said Welsh.
Hopkins last hosted the meet in
1981, as the Newton H. White,
Jr. Athletic Center is one of the
few in the conference which is
suitably equipped.

Jay men's teams have
dominated the conference, and
similar expectations are held for
this year. The Jays have won 15
of the 20 meets held since 1965,
including 14 in a row from 1971
until last year. In 1984, the
men's squad scored a total of
656 points, well above the
runners-up, Dickinson, which
earned 383.
As the list of meet records indicates, the Jays have been
strong in nearly every event.
From the 1985 team, senior cocaptain Dick Johnson and the
800 freestyle relay team of Steve
Segreto, Dan Fritsch, Kevin
Anderson, and Matt Hepler are
record holders.
The Jay women have also
fared well, winning three championships from 1976 to 1978.
Dickinson placed first last year
with 337 points, and Hopkins
came in fourth, 136 points
behind. Gettysburg leads the
conference with four championships, as the women have
only been swimming within the
conference for 10 years.

freshman Dawn Ledbetter placed fourth off the one meter
board and second from the
three meter to earn the Jays 24
points for a fifth place
standing.
According to. Welsh, national
qualifying times can be achieved at any time during the meet,
so the competition will be
uniformly tough. "This is
known as a 'rested and shaved'
meet," he said. "Practices are
toned down in preparation, and
swimmers will often shave
down to increase their times."
Several Blue Jays will use this
opportunity to try for their national cuts. Johnson will attempt the 100 backstroke and
400 individual medley, while his
co-captain Jim Cutrone will try

to qualify in the 1650 freestyle
for the fourth straight year.
Other potential qualifiers are:
Mark Postler, 1650 freestyle;
Alan Barry, 100 and 200
breaststroke; Kevin Anderson,
50, 100, & 200 freestyle, and
100 backstroke. Also attempting national cuts will be the 400
and 800 freestyle relay teams.
On the women's side, the
following are potential
qualifiers: Libby Altman, 100
and 200 breaststroke; Tammy
Smecker, 50 and 100 freestyle;
Katie Jenkins, 100 and 200
freestyle; Holly Flood, 50 and
100 freestyle; Karen Stefanko,
200 butterfly; and Amy
Malcomb, 200 freestyle and 200
individual medley.
Spectators are welcome at all
events, and the stands will probably fill early for the finals.

Squashers Fare Well After Romp by Quakers
by Theresa Zemanavich
Travelling to the University
of Pennsylvania last Friday
afternoon, a stiff group of
Lady Jay squashers faced the
Division II Quakers moments
after disembarking from its
van. Although Penn's No. 1
player was absent, they proved
their superiority by defeating
Hopkins 9-0. "Lavender Lisa"
Roy added the only spark of
hope for the Jays, barely losing
in five games.
Following this confrontation, Penn faced another
recently-arrived team from
Cornell University. Then,as the
Quakers left for home,the Jays
and the Big Red took to the
courts for a clash of their own.
Forfeiting at No. 9, Hopkins
lost a close 4-5 skirmish. Vic-

torious Hopkinsians were No.
1 Jessie Chai, No. 2 Roy, the
ever-gracious No. 3 Ann Ham well, and No. 4 Mary
"Powerhouse" Voytko.
Afterwards, however, Coach
James Goodyear chided the
team captain for losing a game
to her Big Red opponent. "It
shows you're softening up, and
you have to stay tough!" he
reprimanded a sheepish Chai.

Fencers Win Two More to Reach 19-1 Mark
by Steve Forman
Returning to the road after
two weeks at home, the men's
fencing team was able to rack
up two more victories to extend
its win streak to twelve and its
overall record to 19-1. This past
Saturday, Drew and RutgersNewark fell to the Jays.
The Drew meet started out
on a disappointing note. The
Jays dropped the first three
sabre bouts, due in part to what
many considered to be poor

judging. The remainder of the
team did not despair, coming
up with five victories out of the
next six bouts. Tim Cook, Russ
Carstens, and Alex Moen took
all three for the epee team,
while Andy Goldberg and Toby
Chai captured two more to give
the Jays a one bout lead at the
end of the first round.
The next round showed no
let-up, as the three starting
sabremen, Taro Adachi, Wales
Shao, and Chris Calingaert, rebounded from their dismal start

to take all three. The foil and
epee teams, mirroring their first
round performances, again
took five of six; the foilmen
came up with three victories this
time, one of which was by
substitute Charles Greene. At
the end of the round, the meet
score was a convincing 13-5.
Confident with the team's
ability to win the meet, Coach
Oles began to substitute. Matt
Lipton and Louis Liu were
entered in sabre. Liu was able
to take his bout easily; the vic-

Jays Face 1986 Without Puhala
After a disappointing season
which ended last Saturday, the
Blue Jay basketball team has
begun to pick up the pieces and
look towards next year. The
squad, which won 8 of 21
games this season, loses only
one player to graduation in
1985.
The gap, however, will be a
difficult one to fill. Senior captain Ken Puhala has been a sure
performer for the Jays all
season, compiling an 11.2 point

scoring average while starting
every game. The total is third
on the team behind junior
Ralph Horne and sophomore
Steve Mitchell, both of whom
will be counted on for leadership next year.
The Mitchell-Horne combination found some success
this year, as the two accounted
for 565 of the Jays' 1,448
points. Both were dominant
players on the boards compared
to their teammates, though pro-

blems were often encountered
against strong players from
other squads.
Next year's prospects are
already bright. Seven seniors
and five juniors will lead the
team, and to their ranks will be
added five to seven freshman
recruits, according to Head
Coach Nappy Doherty. One
handicap of this year's squad
was that it fielded no freshmen.

The season is now officially
over as far as the team goes, but
the top three players, Chai,
Roy, and Harnwell will remain
in competition for the next two
weeks. Chai journeyed to the
Ricochet Playing Field in New
Jersey last night for National
B's, and, next weekend, two,
perhaps three, will attend Collegiate Nationals at Williams
College in Williamstown, MA.

University President Steven
Muller formally announced a

Muller discussed reasons for the
increase and what tuition
dollars will be spent for. He
also answered questions from
the council about the effects of
cuts in federal student aid, and
about student participation in
university development plans.
The increase would send tuition from $8600 this year to
$9400 for the 1985-86 academic
year.
The university budget committee unanimously approved
the $800 hike last week, Muller
said, and the Board of Trustees
will hear the proposal Friday.
It is extremely unlikely the

Trustees will reject Muller's
recommendation.

Hopkins' tuition today and
next year and into the indefinite
future will remain significantly
below that of other institutions." He distibuted a list to
the council members and halfdozen other students present of
93 prominent American colleges and universities ranked by
1984-1985 tuition rates. Johns
Hopkins is 48th on the list. If
Hopkins moves up on the list
because of the increase, Muller
said, he expects it will be by only a few places. "We really
don't want to raise tuition any
more than we have to," he said.
Muller maintained, however,
that some increase is needed to

and Bryce Quayle.

"Basically, it (the beer
policy) is going to be the same
as last year," Vogelbaum said.

Garden" will be fenced off,

that there will probably be
seven student groups selling
beer, which is the same number
as last year.

groups financially," Vogelbaum said. "It brings in a lot
of money." Vogelbaum added
that this was true for the student groups only if they didn't
"drink away their profits,"

them from doing, he said.

the Fair.

wording.

Johns Hopkins University. As part of the

maturity.

To the Editor:

With the new increase in tuition, Hopkins is going to have
to do something to keep attracting students. I see no other
course than to go the way of St.
John's, Temple, and Apex
Tech and go on T.V. What better way of reaching thousands
of 1300-plus SATers than advertising during All-Star Wrestling?
The number of advertising
possibilities are staggering. I
think the best way is a sale.
Every American loves to think
he's getting a bargain: "All of
our credits are priced to move!
Computers, History, Math,
Writing Seminars, Economics,
Chemistry, and yes, even

brand professors! Everything
must go!" Or maybe those

bargin ads on UHF: "How

at these delights: Pinto Bean

Insensitivity
To the Editor:
Valentine's Day is certainly
not a major holiday. Yet it does
provide the opportunity for expressing one's love for another
person. It was within this con-

text that the cartoon Hopper
appeared in the February 15
edition of the News-Letter. The
message of the strip seemed
clear: Hopper apparently hates
Valentine's Day because he
never received valentines from
the "cool people" in elementary school, but he did receive
valentines from the "faggots"
in high school. Let me suggest
what is wrong with this.
First, the cartoon almsot explicitly connects unpopularity,
or "uncoolness" with homosexuality. Indeed, the adjustments to and expression of
one's homosexuality are not
always easy, but the fact of being a homosexual is hardly
related to one's ability to
achieve success or respect. Unfortunately, the cartoon conveys the more implicit and insidious suggestion that love between or expressed by homosexuals is unacceptable or unnatural. All the more distressing
is the apparent widespread acceptance of this attitude among
the Hopkins community. Such
insensitivity is the very essence
of bigotry. To be sure, the use
of the word "faggot" in a
newspaper which allegedly
represents Hopkins is shocking.
All the academic pestige and
clout of Hopkins does not
justify the use of the word
"faggot" in any context. I can
only imagine what effect this
cartoon had on those who are
struggling with their own sexual
identity, who are frustrated,
confused, or alienated. That
these people on the very
threshold of sexual ambiguity
should be subjected to such
cruelty is reprehensible and unforgivable. I cannot understand
why love—an emotion so
necessary for everyone and
something which bears all
things, believes all things, hopes
all things, endures all things—
why this should be legitimate
for some but not others.
Irrespective of whatever
humorous effect the strip's
message was intended to produce (which I failed to
discover), such a pejorative cartoon should never have been
published. There are universities and communities in the

tbe

United States which would have
not only voiced significant
outrage, but would have
mobilized demonstrations
within hours of the cartoon's
appearance. I have written this
letter to voice my personal
outrage, but whether it will provoke even the slightest reaction
is problematic. It is an attempt,
however small, to break the
tyranny of silence which exists
concerning the problems faced
by homosexuals, both male and
female, in the Hopkins community. It is my hope that those
who feel frustrated, hurt, or
angered, will see that there are
people who care and understand very much, and that they
are not alone.
Scott Henderson
Graduate Student, Department
of History

Letters continued
Continued from Page 6
ter to a friend, and sends it
through the U.S. Mail. The letter contains comments critical
of the local postmaster. It turns
out that the letter cannot be
delivered or returned, so it is
sent to the Dead Letter Office.
The letter is opened and the
contents are passed on to the
postmaster, who then sends a
note to Mr. Carpenter commenting on his letter and
threatening to cut off his mail
delivery.
This is precisely what happened with my electronic letter.
Reading the first few lines(with
the "From:" and "To:"
headings) may have been
necessary to deliver or return it.
However, by concerning
himself with the contents of
private correspondence, David
Binko did commit an invasion
of privacy. His threat of taking
"steps to limit [my] communications to the outside
world to 'AT & Tnet' "—

because of the contents of my
letter—was an attempt to infringe freedom of speech as well.
I commend the editors of
theNews-Letter for their wellwritten editorial that went
directly to the real issue. They,
as well as the Student Council,
recognized that no matter how
legitimately Homewood Computing Facilities personnel obtained access to the letter, it
could not justify Mr. Binko's
subsequent actions.
Johns Hopkins joined the
Bitnet computer network in
order to better serve all
members of the University
community. This includes using
the network for electronic mail
as well as more obviously
"educational" purposes such as
dissertations and up-to-theminute research results. It costs
the University exactly as much
to have the Bitnet connection
used heavily by students, faculty, and staff as it would to have
it sit idly.

Nobody I know has ever continued playing games in
Maryland 109 when someone
needed a terminal for real
work. On the contrary, my
knowlegeable "cronies" and I
have given thousands of hours
of assistance over the last four
years to many people desperately trying to complete computer
projects. I wonder if Mr.
Carpenter has talked to any of
these people. Any of us will
gladly help him take advantage
of the powerful resources of the,
computer networks available to
everyone at this University.
I regret that a faculty
member received negative
publicity through no fault of his
own, but rather because private
correspondence did not stay
private. The entire incident
never should have happened.
Sincerely,
Adlai Waksman, '85

animals. After each extinction,
the very few surviving species
would repopulate the areas
previously inhabited by others.
It was found that the one or
two surviving species after each
extinction were suited to dwell
in colder waters. This suggests
that each extinction coincided
with a drop in sea temperature.
In the last part of the
Mesozoic era, 100 million years
ago, known as the Cretaceous
Period, another remarkable
mass extinction occurred. During the Cretaceous crisis, many
groups of algae were wiped out.
Some of these were the type
that had created large deposits
of chalk on the sea floor, as
seen in the white cliffs of
Dover. During this time reefbuilding rudists, similar to corals, many species of snails, and
all species of ammonoids
(swimming mollusks with spiral
shells), became extinct. This extinction was again characterized by a tropical bias. That is,
species living in warmer
climates were more affected
than others. Other evidence for
cooling includes analyses of
fossil leaves from the period
which indicates a five to twelve
degree (Celcius) drop in
temperature.
The end of the Mesozoic age
was also the end of the age of
dinosaurs. A recent hypothesis
suggests that the extinction of

the great reptiles was caused by
the impact of an asteroid on the
earth. Supposedly, after the impact, large amounts of dust
were raised, obscuring the sun.
The evidence for this is a thin
geologic layer around the world
that contains a higher than
average concentration of
iridium, which is scarce on the
earth's surface while abundant
on asteroids.
This hypothesis, however,
necessarily implies that the extinctions at the end of the
Cretaceous Period would have
been quite sudden. This is not
supported by other evidence.
While some species do indeed
demonstrate a sudden disappearance, many others show a
natural decline in the same
period. Different groups of
organisms declined at different
times during this period over a
duration of two million years.
The mass extinctions Stanley
spoke of were quite extensive.
Some extinctions may have
eliminated up to 90 percent of
marine life and up to half of the
families of organisms. Stanley
did not speculate to a great extent as to what caused the
catastrophic coolings. Possibilities include changing properties of the sun, fluctuations in
the earth's orbit, or volcanic activity causing prolonged
obscuring of the sun.

Needless to say, the traditional remedies equalled or exceeded hospital care. Book is

The movie succeeds so spectacularly because director Weir,

Rachel, too, learns pleasures
she did not know before: the
most simple of songs from
Book's car stereo brings an entirely new enjoyment to her until Grandpa Lapp takes Rachel
to task offscreen, presumably
about the evils of music, dance,
and radio.
In one of the movie's most
memorable scenes, Book puts
his carpentry skills to use as one
of a team that erects an entire
barn in a matter of hours. The
scene demonstrates not only
amazing teamwork, but gives
us further insight into Amish
male/female relations: the men
raise the barn, the women make
the lunch, and everyone involved knows their place.

Sports
by Howard Bregman

The Mid-Atlantic Conference swimming season ends
this weekend as the Johns
Hopkins men's and women's
teams host the 38th annual conference championships at the
Homewood pool. The Jays will
host 13 varsity squads, all seeking team and individual
achievement at the climax of
their dual meet schedules.
,Hopkins Coach Tim Welsh is
looking forward to a competitive meet in both the men's
and women's ranks, as many
swimmers will attempt to
qualify for the Division III National Championships with
their performance at MAC's.
The national meet will be held
in Atlanta late next month.
"MAC's are important to us
in one respect because it is the
only meet to which the whole
team can go," said Welsh.
Hopkins last hosted the meet in
1981, as the Newton H. White,
Jr. Athletic Center is one of the
few in the conference which is
suitably equipped.

Jay men's teams have
dominated the conference, and
similar expectations are held for
this year. The Jays have won 15
of the 20 meets held since 1965,
including 14 in a row from 1971
until last year. In 1984, the
men's squad scored a total of
656 points, well above the
runners-up, Dickinson, which
earned 383.
As the list of meet records indicates, the Jays have been
strong in nearly every event.
From the 1985 team, senior cocaptain Dick Johnson and the
800 freestyle relay team of Steve
Segreto, Dan Fritsch, Kevin
Anderson, and Matt Hepler are
record holders.
The Jay women have also
fared well, winning three championships from 1976 to 1978.
Dickinson placed first last year
with 337 points, and Hopkins
came in fourth, 136 points
behind. Gettysburg leads the
conference with four championships, as the women have
only been swimming within the
conference for 10 years.

freshman Dawn Ledbetter placed fourth off the one meter
board and second from the
three meter to earn the Jays 24

standing.
According to. Welsh, national
qualifying times can be achieved at any time during the meet,
so the competition will be
uniformly tough. "This is
known as a 'rested and shaved'
meet," he said. "Practices are
toned down in preparation, and
swimmers will often shave
down to increase their times."
Several Blue Jays will use this
opportunity to try for their national cuts. Johnson will attempt the 100 backstroke and
400 individual medley, while his
co-captain Jim Cutrone will try

to qualify in the 1650 freestyle
for the fourth straight year.
Other potential qualifiers are:
Mark Postler, 1650 freestyle;
Alan Barry, 100 and 200
breaststroke; Kevin Anderson,
50, 100, & 200 freestyle, and
100 backstroke. Also attempting national cuts will be the 400
and 800 freestyle relay teams.
On the women's side, the
following are potential
qualifiers: Libby Altman, 100
and 200 breaststroke; Tammy
Smecker, 50 and 100 freestyle;
Katie Jenkins, 100 and 200
freestyle; Holly Flood, 50 and
100 freestyle; Karen Stefanko,
200 butterfly; and Amy
Malcomb, 200 freestyle and 200
individual medley.
Spectators are welcome at all
events, and the stands will probably fill early for the finals.

Fencers Win Two More to Reach 19-1 Mark
by Steve Forman
Returning to the road after
two weeks at home, the men's
fencing team was able to rack
up two more victories to extend
its win streak to twelve and its
overall record to 19-1. This past
Saturday, Drew and RutgersNewark fell to the Jays.
The Drew meet started out
on a disappointing note. The
Jays dropped the first three
sabre bouts, due in part to what
many considered to be poor

judging. The remainder of the
team did not despair, coming
up with five victories out of the
next six bouts. Tim Cook, Russ
Carstens, and Alex Moen took
all three for the epee team,
while Andy Goldberg and Toby
Chai captured two more to give
the Jays a one bout lead at the
end of the first round.
The next round showed no
let-up, as the three starting
sabremen, Taro Adachi, Wales
Shao, and Chris Calingaert, rebounded from their dismal start

to take all three. The foil and
epee teams, mirroring their first
round performances, again
took five of six; the foilmen
came up with three victories this
time, one of which was by
substitute Charles Greene. At
the end of the round, the meet
score was a convincing 13-5.
Confident with the team's
ability to win the meet, Coach
Oles began to substitute. Matt
Lipton and Louis Liu were
entered in sabre. Liu was able
to take his bout easily; the vic-

Jays Face 1986 Without Puhala
After a disappointing season
which ended last Saturday, the
Blue Jay basketball team has
begun to pick up the pieces and
look towards next year. The
squad, which won 8 of 21
games this season, loses only
one player to graduation in
1985.
The gap, however, will be a
difficult one to fill. Senior captain Ken Puhala has been a sure
performer for the Jays all
season, compiling an 11.2 point

scoring average while starting
every game. The total is third
on the team behind junior
Ralph Horne and sophomore
Steve Mitchell, both of whom
will be counted on for leadership next year.
The Mitchell-Horne combination found some success
this year, as the two accounted
for 565 of the Jays' 1,448
points. Both were dominant
players on the boards compared
to their teammates, though pro-

blems were often encountered
against strong players from
other squads.
Next year's prospects are
already bright. Seven seniors
and five juniors will lead the
team, and to their ranks will be
added five to seven freshman
recruits, according to Head
Coach Nappy Doherty. One
handicap of this year's squad
was that it fielded no freshmen.

The season is now officially
over as far as the team goes, but
the top three players, Chai,
Roy, and Harnwell will remain
in competition for the next two
weeks. Chai journeyed to the
Ricochet Playing Field in New
Jersey last night for National
B's, and, next weekend, two,
perhaps three, will attend Collegiate Nationals at Williams
College in Williamstown, MA.
